His name is found on the Arsenal’s WWII Memorial alongside the other former employees of Picatinny who gave their lives in service to our country.   A grateful nation thanks you Pvt. Brodish.

Pvt. Brodish got to work removing projectiles and rockets from the shoreline. That afternoon he was killed when a German artillery projectile exploded over his position on the beach.   Brodish was just 22. He now rests at Normandy American Cemetery.

As we approach the 75th anniversary of D-Day this Memorial Day I’m honoring William J. Brodish.    William worked at Picatinny Arsenal then joined the Army. As a member of the 27th Ordnance Bomb Disposal Squad he landed on Omaha Beach the morning of June 6 1944. #DDay75 https://t.co/rhBNYNDJq0
